discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BCD
B, C and D are correct

choices.D: The SET ROLE statement can disable one or more roles for a session.
choices.B: The SET ROLE statement can enable one or more roles for a session.
choices.A: Object privileges may not be granted to roles.
choices.C: Roles may be granted to roles.
choices.E: All roles granted to a user are set on by default when the user logs in

questions.question_text: Which three statements are true about roles? (Choose three.)

Examine this query:

SELECT TRUNC(ROUND(156.00,-2),-1) FROM DUAL

What is the result?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: E
Correct answer: E
Rounding 156.00 to the nearest hundred (-2) gives 200.
Truncating 200 to the nearest ten (-1) will still give 200

choices.C: Uncommitted transactions are allowed to continue to the next ROLLBACK.
choices.F: New connection requests made to the database instance are refused.
choices.B: Uncommitted transactions are allowed to continue to the next COMMIT.
choices.D: Instance recovery occurs automatically during the shutdown.
choices.A: Sessions remain connected even if they are not running a transaction.
choices.E: Instance recovery occurs at the next restart.

questions.question_text:
Which three statements are true about the Oracle Database server during and immediately after
SHUTDOWN TRANSACTIONAL? (Choose three.)

comments.content: indeed, there is nothing to recover if all the transactions finished properly !

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BCF
shutdown TRANSACTIONAL:
Specifies that a transactional shutdown is to be performed. A transactional shutdown prevents new user logins and disconnects any user whose transaction is complete (i.e., no COMMIT is pending). As each remaining user completes the current transaction via a COMMIT or ROLLBACK statement, the session is disconnected. When all users are disconnected, the instance will be shut down.

so BCF
for D,E 
The Instance Recovery will only happen if issuing shutdown abort or a crash.

Selected Answer: BDF
B, D, F

B: Transactions that haven't been committed yet are allowed to finish before shutdown fully completes
D: Database will automatically check for any unfinished transactions and make sure everything is in a consistent state
F: New users trying to log in or start sessions will be denied access until the database is fully shut down and restarted

Selected Answer: ABE
A: Reduces the redo generated.
B: Allows DML over GTT even in read-only mode.
E: Minimize use of undo tablespace.

Selected Answer: BDE
B, D, E

B: Undo tablespace is typically locked in read-only mode. Using temp undo allows DML operations to occur on global temporary tables even in a read-only database
D: By using temp UNDO, the system avoids unnecessary writes to SYSTEM tablespace, which improves performance by reducing I/O operations
E: Usage of UNDO space in the UNDO tablespace is minimized since the UNDO for DML operations is stored in temporary storage

questions.question_text: Which three are benefits of using temp UNDO when performing DML on global temporary tables? (Choose three.)

choices.C: It reduces I/Os to the SYSAUX tablespace.
choices.D: It reduces I/Os to the SYSTEM tablespace.
choices.A: It reduces the amount of redo generated.
choices.E: It reduces the amount of UNDO stored in the UNDO tablespace.
choices.B: It permits DML on Global temporary tables even if the database is opened read only.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
provided answer is correct.
for A,B,E: need to be the same number of result, otherwise "ora-01789 query block has incorrect number of result columns" will happen
